awd_titl_txt: Mapping Matter in Strong Gravity: Spectral-Timing of Black Holes and Neutron Stars
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Michigan State University Dept. of Physics and Astronomy

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project focused on black holes and neutron stars, which are the dead remnants of very massive and somewhat-massive stars. Black holes and neutron stars together are called "compact objects" because, at a macroscopic distance, they're more alike than different. Compact objects play host to extreme physics that we can learn about due to the effects they have on the space environments around them. A compact object often has a companion star that is a regular star like our Sun. The compact object and its companion orbit around each other, bound together by gravity, and they're close enough that the compact object slowly eats its friend. As it drains material from the companion and gathers it together to eat it, this material gets more than 100 times hotter than the surface of the Sun and shines very bright X-ray light. These systems are called X-ray binaries, and we have seen many of them in our Milky Way galaxy and other galaxies with X-ray space telescopes like NICER and NuSTAR. X-ray binaries are too small and too far away to take a detailed image, so they appear as a single dot or pixel in the telescope -- if we wanted to take a picture of the event horizon of a black hole in an X-ray binary in our galaxy, the equivalent imaging resolution would be like trying to see the width of a human hair on the surface of Mars. To gain an understanding of the hot inner regions of X-ray binaries, we turn to measurements of how the X-ray light varies in brightness and X-ray color. In this NSF project, we used a novel data analysis technique to look at very rapid, sub-second variability coming from the hot star stuff around black holes and neutron stars in X-ray binaries to build a picture of the geometry of matter in the curved spacetime around these extreme objects.


The scientific discoveries and advancements associated with this NSF project have been published in 10 peer-reviewed journal papers and 11 unrefereed professional publications, and have been presented in 18 invited conference talks, seminars and colloquia. The Stingray spectral-timing software package, which contains the analysis tools used in this and related work, has had major and minor version releases.

The Broader Impacts aim of the project is to lead curiosity-driven astronomy and physics lessons with local middle school students, particularly those from local underprivileged schools. Interest in STEM is sparked in the middle school years, so working with this age group encourages the students to consider astronomy research and other STEM disciplines as possible career paths. Furthermore, making science entertaining and accessible by incorporating scientific concepts in art and storytelling re-introduces adults to the joy of science. This engagement happens via public talks, performances, and workshops.

Outreach activities:

  • 20+ virtual classroom lessons with Skype A Scientist about astronomy and space science for all grades, virtual
  • 15+ in-person and virtual classroom lessons with MSU Science Festival about black holes and gravity for grades 6-8 in the Lansing, MI area
  • Activity leader for Make Your Own Pulsar! for multiple school groups at MSU Science Festival school program day
  • Activity leader for Make Your Own Pulsar! for about 300 kids grades K-8 over 6 hours at MSU Science Festival Expo Day
  • Volunteer with the Spartan Young Astronomers Club for ages 8-13
  • Volunteer at several MSU Observatory public observing nights
  • Invited speaker for the MSU chapter of the Society for Women In Space Exploration (SWISE)
  • Invited keynote presenter for the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada, Calgary centre
  • "JWST Day" planner and lead at the Abrams Planetarium
  • Panel on social media in science communication at the 2021 FORCE11 conference
  • Podcast guest on "Abstract: The Future of Science" with Jeremy Ullman
  • Lecturer on "How Can We 'See' Black Holes?" for the Great Lakes Lectures series
  • Astronomer for the Skype A Scientist "May The Fourth" 2021 Star Wars
  • Presenter and finalist in the Skype A Scientist "No Time Like The Presentation!" 2021 competition
  • Virtual talks for families for the Abrams Planetarium and MSU Science Festival in East Lansing
  • Invited panelist for "Adler After Dark: Out in Space" at the Adler Planetarium in Chicago
  • 4x invited speaker at Astronomy On Tap Lansing
  • Writer and presenter, REO Town Reading Series in Lansing, MI
  • Presenter, Schrodinger's Cat Is In Town II workshop, MSU Broad Museum Art Lab
  • Multiple interviews with the Associated Press, MSU branch, about recent astronomy news about black holes and neutron stars
